problem: A particle executes simple harmonic motion with frequency f. The frequency with which its kinetic energy oscillates is ____.

scenes.title: Introduction — SHM overview

narration_segments.text: This animation shows simple harmonic motion and the variation of kinetic and potential energy.
A particle moves to and fro about an equilibrium position performing simple harmonic motion.

visual_actions: Draw horizontal axis with equilibrium marker labeled 'O'.
Show particle performing SHM between −A and +A with labeled amplitudes.

scenes.title: Energy variation during motion

narration_segments.text: As the particle moves, kinetic and potential energies vary with time.

visual_actions: Display red bar for kinetic energy and green bar for potential energy.
Bars vary in opposite phase as the particle moves.

scenes.title: Mathematical explanation

narration_segments.text: Let us understand this mathematically. The displacement of the particle in simple harmonic motion is given by x equals A, cos omega t.
Omega which represents angular frequency is two pi f.
So we can represent the displacement A, cos two pi f t.
Differentiating with respect to time gives the velocity, v, equals minus two pi f A sine two pi f t.
Kinetic energy is half, m, v squared, so substituting for, v, we get.
Using the trigonometric identity sine squared theta equals one minus cos two theta over two.
So we can say that the kinetic energy is proportional to one minus cos four pi f t over two, which means new angular frequency is two omega.
This shows that the kinetic energy varies with time with a frequency of four pi f divided by two pi, which is two f.

visual_actions: Show sequential MathTex equations for x(t), v(t), KE, trigonometric identity, and final frequency relation.
Highlight the term indicating frequency doubling.

scenes.title: Conclusion

narration_segments.text: Therefore, the kinetic energy oscillates with frequency two f.

visual_actions: Display final highlighted answer text 'Answer: 2f' in yellow.
Show a short recap animation summarizing frequency doubling.

final_notes.concept_summary: Kinetic energy depends on v squared which introduces cos squared term, doubling the oscillation frequency.
